come in.translation[0].definitions[0].de: if a train, bus, plane, or ship comes in, it arrives at a place
come in.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: What time does your train come in?
We come in to Heathrow at nine in the morning.
come in.translation[0].definitions[1].de: if money or information comes in, you receive it
come in.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Reports are coming in of a massive earthquake in Mexico.
We haven’t got enough money coming in.
come in.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to be involved in a plan, deal etc
come in.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: We need some financial advice – that’s where Kate comes in.
You had the chance to come in on the deal.
come in.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to join in a conversation or discussion
come in.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Can I come in here and add something to what you’re saying?
come in.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: Trainers really became popular in the 1980s, when casual sportswear came in.
come in.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: His horse came in second to last.
come in.translation[0].definitions[6].de: if the tide comes in, the sea moves towards the land and covers the edge of it
come in.translation[1].definitions[0].de: used to tell someone who has knocked on your door to enter your room, house etc
come in.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: She tapped timidly on the door. ‘Come in!’ boomed a deep voice from inside.
